column1: Table 4. Senegal: Budgetary Central Government Operations, GFSM 2001 Classification,
Taxes on income, profits, capital gains                               559          603           700            740           856          947           1,097        1,211
Taxes on international trade and transactions                        266          290           345            437           501          567             648          715
Transactions in financial assets and liabilities (Financing)             -362          -472          -523           -452          -489         -538            -621         -687
T-bills and bonds issued in WAEMU                                -180          -279            14            141           -54          111             144          159
Sources: Ministry of Finance; and IMF staff estimates and projections.
Starting in 2016, Treasury operations to finance (i) Post office operations (Poste and Poste Finance), (ii) pensions (Fonds National de Retraites), (iii) reduction of stock
of comptes de depots, (iv) arrears to energy sector.
This is total hydrocarbon revenues accruing to the Senegalese government and is higher than what is annually included in the budget of the central government
Public Investment differs from net acquisition of nonfinancial assets reported in the fiscal tables by including public spending in wages and salaries of frontline staff
in education and health, both of which are considered as investment in human capital (in line with the spirit of the PSE).
One-off operation to allow clearance of central government unmet obligations vis-à-vis the national electricity company SENELEC. This is mostly linked to
compensation for subsidized electricity tariffs dating from the period 2017-2018.
